Introduction

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is a benign ocular condition characterized by bleeding beneath the conjunctiva, the transparent mucous membrane covering the sclera (the white part of the eye) and lining the eyelids.  It typically presents as a painless red patch on the sclera.  Many arise spontaneously or follow minor trauma or a Valsalva maneuver (eg, coughing, straining).

Pathogenesis and risk factors



A subconjunctival hemorrhage occurs when a small conjunctival blood vessel ruptures, allowing blood to accumulate between the conjunctiva and the sclera (

image 1
).  Because the conjunctiva is loosely adherent to the underlying sclera, even a small amount of bleeding can spread extensively over the ocular surface.  Hemorrhage is typically limited by the limbus (border between cornea and sclera), so the cornea remains clear and vision is unaffected.  Over the course of 1-3 weeks, the extravasated blood is gradually broken down and resorbed by local macrophages and lymphatic drainage.



A subconjunctival hemorrhage may occur spontaneously or result from minor trauma (eg, eye rubbing, contact lens insertion) or a sudden increase in venous pressure during a Valsalva maneuver (eg, coughing, sneezing, straining).  Additional risk factors include systemic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy, and bleeding diatheses (eg, hemophilia, thrombocytopenia).  In older adults, fragile conjunctival vessels and age-related vascular changes further increase susceptibility.

Clinical presentation



  • Well-demarcated, bright or dark red patch on the scleral surface (
    image 2
    ).
  • Normal visual acuity.
  • Painless (possible mild foreign body sensation).
  • No discharge, photophobia, edema, or tearing.


Red flags suggesting a more serious etiology include recurrent or bilateral hemorrhages, pain or visual changes, signs of a systemic bleeding disorder (eg, cutaneous bruising, gum bleeding), and a history of significant ocular trauma (eg, blunt force to the orbit).

Differential diagnosis



  • Conjunctivitis (
    image 3
    ):  Inflammation of the conjunctiva due to infection or allergy.  It presents with eye irritation or discomfort, watery or purulent discharge, and diffuse conjunctival redness.
  • Episcleritis (
    image 4
    ):  Self-limited inflammation of blood vessels within the episclera (membrane between the conjunctiva and the sclera).  The condition is usually idiopathic or due to autoimmune disease and typically presents with sudden-onset localized redness, mild irritation, and tearing.
  • Scleritis:  Inflammation of the sclera, often associated with systemic autoimmune diseases.  It causes intense, boring eye pain, which may radiate to the temple or jaw, as well as diffuse eye redness with a purplish hue, tenderness to palpation, and visual impairment.
  • Keratitis (
    image 5
    ):  Infection or inflammation of the cornea that presents with significant eye pain, blurred vision, photophobia, tearing, scleral injection, and a corneal opacity or infiltrate on examination.
  • Corneal abrasion (
    image 6
    ):  A defect in the corneal epithelium that causes severe eye pain, foreign body sensation, tearing, and diffuse redness.  Patients often have photophobia and trouble keeping the eye open.  Abrasions can be visualized with fluorescein staining under a Wood lamp.
  • Hyphema (
    image 7
    ):  Accumulation of red blood cells in the anterior chamber, typically following blunt ocular trauma that ruptures vessels of the iris or ciliary body.  This can cause eye pain, photophobia, elevated intraocular pressure, and decreased visual acuity, with visible layering of blood behind the cornea.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is clinical based on the distinctive appearance (focal area of scleral redness) and the absence of eye pain, photophobia, discharge, or visual disturbance.



Physical examination should confirm that the hemorrhage is confined to the subconjunctival space to exclude deeper or more serious pathology.  Key components of the ocular examination may include visual acuity testing, fluorescein staining, slit-lamp evaluation, and intraocular pressure measurement.



Laboratory testing is typically unnecessary for isolated, first-time cases.  However, work-up may be indicated if hemorrhages are recurrent or bilateral, there are other bleeding manifestations, or the patient has had anticoagulation.  Testing may include a platelet count, PT/INR, activated PTT, hemoglobin, and hemoglobin A1c.  In addition, imaging (eg, CT scan of the orbit) is not required unless significant blunt ocular trauma has occurred and there is concern for globe rupture or other injuries (eg, retroorbital hematoma).

Management



Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a benign, self-limited condition that requires no specific treatment beyond reassurance.  The hemorrhage may spread initially, fade to yellow, and then disappear completely within 1-3 weeks.  Patients should be advised to avoid eye rubbing, Valsalva maneuvers, and strenuous activity that could increase venous pressure or precipitate recurrence.



Ophthalmology follow-up is generally unnecessary for isolated cases, but should be considered if episodes are recurrent, bilateral, or slow to resolve.  Predisposing conditions (eg, uncontrolled hypertension, diabetes mellitus, excessive anticoagulation, chronic cough/constipation) should be managed to reduce risk.

Summary



A subconjunctival hemorrhage is a benign eye condition that results from the rupture of small conjunctival blood vessels, often triggered by minor trauma or Valsalva maneuvers.  It presents as a bright red patch on the sclera and is typically asymptomatic and self-limited.  Diagnosis is clinical, and most cases do not require work-up or treatment.
